clinical_study.brief_title: Assessment of Feasibility and Acceptability of Personalized Breast Cancer Screening
clinical_study.official_title: Personalized Breast Cancer Screening: Assessment of Its Feasibility and Acceptability in the National Health System

primary_outcome.measure: Attitude towards personalised breast cancer screening (by participant women)
primary_outcome.time_frame: 2-4 weeks after being informed of the individual breast cancer risk
primary_outcome.description: Attitude scale with three items, one about the frequency of screening exams (ranges from 1 to 5). The other two items ask if participants are satisfied of being invited more/less frequently, in case that they have a higher/lower risk of breast cancer than the average women. They also range from 1 to 5. Total scores can range from 3 to 15. Higher scores indicate more positive attitudes. A positive attitude is defined as a total score greater or equal to 12. Adapted from Hersch et al. (2015)

primary_outcome.measure: Intention to participate in personalised breast cancer screening
primary_outcome.time_frame: 2-4 weeks after being informed of the individual breast cancer risk
primary_outcome.description: Categorical variable with five categories: definitely will, likely to, unsure, not likely to, definitely will not. The absolute and relative frequencies of the five categories will be obtained. In addition, the variable will be dichotomized as intending to participate (definitely or likely) or not. Adapted from Hersch et al. (2015)

primary_outcome.time_frame: At 1 year of the study start
primary_outcome.description: Satisfaction Likert scale with one item that ranges from 1 to 5: not at all satisfied (1), extremely satisfied (5). Following the Sekhon et al. review (2017)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2-4 weeks after being informed of the individual breast cancer risk
secondary_outcome.description: General attitudes scale towards screening mammography. It will be measured using five items adapted from Hersch et al. (2015). Each item ranges from 1 to 5. Total scores can range from 5 to 25. A positive attitude is defined as a total score greater or equal to 20. Higher scores indicate more positive attitudes. Adapted from Hersch et al. (2015)

secondary_outcome.measure: Attitude towards the measure of breast cancer risk
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2-4 weeks after being informed of the individual breast cancer risk
secondary_outcome.description: One categorical variable with four categories. It asks if the measure of breast cancer risk will do more harm than good, more good than harm, it depends, do not know. The absolute and relative frequencies of the four categories will be obtained. Following the Sekhon et al. review (2017)

secondary_outcome.measure: Emotional impact of the measure of breast cancer risk
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2-4 weeks after being informed of the individual breast cancer risk
secondary_outcome.description: Three categorical variables with five categories, ranging from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5). First variable: The information about the individual risk of breast cancer provides calmness. Second variable: Receiving information about risks produces anxiety. Third variable: The information about the individual risk of breast cancer makes me worry. The scores of the three items will not be added as a scale, they will be reported separately. Adapted from Hersch et al. (2015)

secondary_outcome.measure: Preference with regard to the current screening, biennial between 50 and 69 years
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2-4 weeks after being informed of the individual breast cancer risk
secondary_outcome.description: Categorical variable with three categories. It asks what type of screening the participants would choose (personalized risk-based or "one-size-fits-all")

secondary_outcome.measure: Knowledge of the benefits and harms of breast cancer screening
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2-4 weeks after being informed of the individual breast cancer risk
secondary_outcome.description: Eleven conceptual knowledge questions (Yes/No) and four numerical knowledge questions with categories on the effect of screening. A total of 22 marks could be obtained, 11 coming from the questions on conceptual knowledge and 11 coming from the questions on numerical knowledge that measured absolute and relative values of the screening outcomes. The threshold to define adequate knowledge is to score at least 50% of the available marks, including at least one numerical mark, on all the three screening outcome subscales that refer to mortality reduction, overdiagnosis, and false positives. Adapted from Hersch et al. (2015)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2-4 weeks after being informed of the individual breast cancer risk
secondary_outcome.description: O'Connor Decisional Conflict Scale, 10-item low literacy version, on a scale from 0 (no decisional conflict) to 100 (extreme decisional conflict). Scores less than 25 are associated with implementing decisions; score exceeding 37.5 are associated with decision delay or feeling unsure about implementation.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2-4 weeks after being informed of the individual breast cancer risk
secondary_outcome.description: Three Likert scale statements rated from 1 (not at all confident) to 5 (very confident). A total score is obtained summing the scores of the three items and dividing by three. Adapted from the O'Connor Decision Self-Efficacy Scale

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2-4 weeks after being informed of the individual breast cancer risk
secondary_outcome.description: Six-item short form of the Spielberger State Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) on a scale from 20 to 80, with higher scores indicating greater levels of anxiety. To calculate the total STAI score, reverse scoring of the positive items (calm, relaxed, content), sum all six scores and multiply total score by 20/6.

secondary_outcome.measure: Perceived significance of the benefits and the adverse effects of screening
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2-4 weeks after being informed of the individual breast cancer risk
secondary_outcome.description: Women will be asked how important it is for them to consider the chances of (1) avoiding breast cancer death, (2) being diagnosed and treated for a cancer that is not harmful, and (3) having a false positive. The four response options range from very important (1) to not at all important (4). The scores of the three items will not be added as a scale, they will be reported separately. According to Hersch et al. (2015)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2-4 weeks after being informed of the individual breast cancer risk
secondary_outcome.description: Four items ranging from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5). Total scores can range from 4 to 20. Higher scores indicate higher self-efficacy. Following the Sekhon et al. review (2017)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2-4 weeks after being informed of the individual breast cancer risk
secondary_outcome.description: It will be measured using five items. Each item ranges from 1 to 5. Total scores can range from 5 to 25. A positive assessment is defined as a total score greater or equal to 20. Higher scores indicate more positive experience assessment. Following the Sekhon et al. review (2017)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2-4 weeks after being informed of the individual breast cancer risk
secondary_outcome.description: Confidence Likert scale with one item ranging from very low confidence (1) to very high confidence (5) . Following the Sekhon et al. review (2017)

secondary_outcome.measure: Understanding of the individual risk and the screening recommendations
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2-4 weeks after being informed of the individual breast cancer risk
secondary_outcome.description: Two categorical variables with five categories each, ranging from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5). First variable: I understood the information I received about my risk of breast cancer in relation to women of my age. Second variable: I have understood the recommendations given to me about the screening of breast cancer in the coming years, based on my risk of breast cancer. The scores of the two items will not be added as a scale, they will be reported separately. Following the Sekhon et al. review (2017)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At the time of communicating risk, 2-4 weeks after the baseline visit
secondary_outcome.description: Continuous variable, number of minutes. Recorded by the participant doctors

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of women who accept to participate in the study
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1.75 years
secondary_outcome.description: Number of women that accept to participate divided by number of women contacted

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of participating women who complete the different phases of the study
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1.75 years
secondary_outcome.description: Number of women that complete the different phases divided by number of participating women

intervention.description: Breast cancer risk measurement, screening recommendations and shared decision making

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Not having had a mammogram in the last 12 months or with a mammogram in this period available to evaluate breast density.
- Sign the informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Previous diagnosis of breast cancer.
- Breast study in process.
- Fulfill clinical criteria defined by the Medical Oncology Spanish Society (SEOM to refer to the genetic counseling unit in cancer.
- Do not understand or speak Catalan or Spanish.
- Cognitive disability for mental or mental illness.
- Physical disability that prevents a mammogram.
